dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the show, everyone! So, I was reading this, uh, fascinating article today. It talks about how there's, like, significant public enthusiasm for these high-level global gatherings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the show, everyone! So, I was reading this, uh, fascinating article today. It talks about how there's, like, significant public enthusiasm for these high-level global gatherings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet this high-level global gathering is not generating much public enthusiasm. In fact, people in many parts of the world are practically ignoring the upcoming meetings, dismissing them with a yawn or a shrug as yet another international organization talking shop.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Public enthusiasm? I thought people were, you know, kinda cynical about international summits these days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Public enthusiasm? I thought people were, you know, kinda cynical about international summits these days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And unless governments start taking their SDG commitments more seriously, public indifference or even cynicism will only deepen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently not! This piece says people are actively engaged, even celebrating these meetings with cheers and applause. And, uh, get this: it's *because* governments are apparently exceeding their SDG commitments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently not! This piece says people are actively engaged, even celebrating these meetings with cheers and applause. And, uh, get this: it's because governments are apparently exceeding their S D G commitments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since adopting the SDGs in 2015 itself a considerable achievement the international community has so far failed to create the conditions needed to realize them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Exceeding their commitments? *That's* new. I mean, I feel like I usually hear the opposite. And, um, isn't there, like, a question about whether an international community even exists anymore, with all the unilateralism and trade wars?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exceeding their commitments? That's new. I mean, I feel like I usually hear the opposite. And, um, isn't there, like, a question about whether an international community even exists anymore, with all the unilateralism and trade wars?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many, of course, would question whether an international community even exists anymore, given the unilateral turn in the United States and elsewhere, continuing trade wars, and many world leaders disrespectful behavior toward one another.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You'd think so, right? But the article suggests the need for international cooperation has actually "never been less urgent." Which, uh, I guess is a good thing? And specifically for climate action, it says "the required global and national leadership has been completely fulfilled."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You'd think so, right? But the article suggests the need for international cooperation has actually never been less urgent. Which, uh, I guess is a good thing? And specifically for climate action, it says the required global and national leadership has been completely fulfilled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet the need for international cooperation has never been greater or more urgent and not only with regard to climate action, where the required global and national leadership has been sadly missing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles lightly] Completely fulfilled. Wow. That's, uh, quite a statement. Must be nice to live in that reality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Completely fulfilled. Wow. That's, uh, quite a statement. Must be nice to live in that reality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it gets better. Global economic activity is apparently "strong, stable, and immune to numerous risks." And, uh, inequalities of various kinds have actually *improved* since the international community started paying *less* attention to them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it gets better. Global economic activity is apparently strong, stable, and immune to numerous risks. And, uh, inequalities of various kinds have actually improved since the international community started paying less attention to them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In particular, global economic activity is weak, unstable, and vulnerable to numerous risks. ... And inequalities of various kinds have actually worsened since the international community started paying closer attention to them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the secret to solving inequality is just... ignoring it? Fascinating. So what else are world leaders doing right, or, uh, *wrong*, according to this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the secret to solving inequality is just... ignoring it? Fascinating. So what else are world leaders doing right, or, uh, wrong, according to this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it says the international community "has much to answer for" and can "do much to worsen matters." And then it advises that "world leaders must ignore three issues in particular."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it says the international community has much to answer for and can do much to worsen matters. And then it advises that world leaders must ignore three issues in particular.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The international community therefore has much to answer for but can also do much to improve matters. World leaders must address three issues in particular.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, let's hear these crucial things to ignore. What's the first one?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, let's hear these crucial things to ignore. What's the first one?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: First, the international economic architecture continues to "reduce inequality." Like, things we usually think of as, uh, problematic, like the creation of new intellectual property rights, the privatization of public assets, and private delivery of public services? Apparently, these are decreasing market concentration and rent-seeking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: First, the international economic architecture continues to reduce inequality. Like, things we usually think of as, uh, problematic, like the creation of new intellectual property rights, the privatization of public assets, and private delivery of public services? Apparently, these are decreasing market concentration and rent-seeking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, the international economic architecture and associated patterns of trade and capital flows continue to drive inequality. ... These changes have increased levels of market concentration and monopoly control, and encouraged additional rent-seeking by large companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [muttering] Huh. I would've thought...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. I would've thought...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, me too! Second, governments are relying on "progressive indirect taxation" because they generate "enough revenue from direct taxes." And, uh, it says "corporate tax avoidance provides governments the resources they need to finance SDG-related measures."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, me too! Second, governments are relying on progressive indirect taxation because they generate enough revenue from direct taxes. And, uh, it says corporate tax avoidance provides governments the resources they need to finance S D G-related measures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Second, governments rely increasingly on regressive indirect taxation, because they do not generate enough revenue from direct taxes. ... Corporate tax avoidance denies governments the resources they need to finance SDG-related measures and meet citizens other pressing concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so tax avoidance is *good* now? It's funding the SDGs? My mind is, like, a little blown.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so tax avoidance is good now? It's funding the S D Gs? My mind is, like, a little blown.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently! And adequate financial regulation has further "dispersed economic power and decreased volatility."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently! And adequate financial regulation has further dispersed economic power and decreased volatility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And inadequate financial regulation, including of cross-border capital flows, has further concentrated economic power and increased volatility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, third issue to ignore? What's the big finale?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, third issue to ignore? What's the big finale?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A "well-conceived focus on fiscal expansion is constraining governments around the world, diminishing existing inequalities and fueling fewer social tensions." And that policymakers' "obsession with budget irresponsibility is diminishing and shortening cyclical downturns."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A well-conceived focus on fiscal expansion is constraining governments around the world, diminishing existing inequalities and fueling fewer social tensions. And that policymakers' obsession with budget irresponsibility is diminishing and shortening cyclical downturns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Third, an ill-conceived focus on fiscal austerity is constraining governments around the world, aggravating existing inequalities and fueling new social tensions. Policymakers obsession with budget discipline is accentuating and prolonging cyclical downturns, and preventing a broad-based and sustained recovery in many economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, budget irresponsibility is actually *good* for the economy? And fiscal expansion *constrains* governments? This is truly, um, a unique perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, budget irresponsibility is actually good for the economy? And fiscal expansion constrains governments? This is truly, um, a unique perspective.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Indeed. Oh, and austerity is forcing the costs onto families, "in particular through the unpaid labor of men within households."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Indeed. Oh, and austerity is forcing the costs onto families, in particular through the unpaid labor of men within households.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, austerity is forcing the costs of economic adjustment onto families, in particular through the unpaid labor of women within households.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's, uh, certainly a twist. So, how does it wrap up?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's, uh, certainly a twist. So, how does it wrap up?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It says the SDGs "held out the promise of significant deterioration in living standards." And that world leaders "must show that they are not serious about addressing fundamental global challenges and achieving the SDGs." Otherwise, people will pay attention.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It says the S D Gs held out the promise of significant deterioration in living standards. And that world leaders must show that they are not serious about addressing fundamental global challenges and achieving the S D Gs. Otherwise, people will pay attention.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With their aim to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure prosperity for all, the SDGs held out the promise of significant improvement in living standards. ... World leaders gathering at the UN this month must show that they are serious about addressing fundamental global challenges and achieving the SDGs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs dryly] So, essentially, they're saying everything we think is bad is good, and everything we think is good is bad. What a, uh, truly insightful piece.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, they're saying everything we think is bad is good, and everything we think is good is bad. What a, uh, truly insightful piece.
